It is used to subscribe to events of editors that are not yet opened. It also exposes global settings and common editor tools.

member.name: T:FarNet.IEditor
member.summary: Editor operator. Exposed as . Created by .
member.remarks:
Normally this object should be created or requested, used instantly and never kept for future use. When you need the current editor operator next time call again to get it.
In fact all dynamic members operate on the current editor, not on the editor associated with the instance. Thus, if you use an operator of not current editor then results may be unexpected.
The editor has members making it semantically similar to a list of lines and strings. These members are: (line count), (gets a line by its index), (removes a line by its index), (removes all lines), \ (adds\inserts text line(s)).
Still, the editor is not a standard list of strings or lines. Standard string list is , it has all useful list members implemented. Standard line lists are or , they have members mostly for reading.

member.name: M:FarNet.IEditor.BeginAsync
member.summary: Begins asynchronous mode.
member.remarks:
This mode is designed for writing text to a not current editor or from background jobs. The editor is partially blocked until the mode is not closed by . Actual writing happens when the editor has or gets focus, otherwise data are queued.
In this mode data are always appended to the end of the current text, so that the output procedure is similar to console output.
Only Insert* methods should be called during asynchronous mode even if you can call something else technically without problems.
Input events (keys, mouse, idle) are disabled in asynchronous mode. There is only a special event that can be used for example for stopping the mode by a user.
Nested calls of are not allowed.
Use this mode only when it is absolutely needed.
Module PowerShellFar uses this mode for asynchronous editor consoles.

member.name: M:FarNet.IEditor.EndAsync
member.summary: Ends asynchronous mode.
member.remarks: It must be called after when asynchronous operations complete. Note: it is OK to call it when asynchronous mode is already stopped or even was not started.

member.name: P:FarNet.IEditor.Lines
member.summary: Gets the list of editor lines.

remarks.para: WARNING: This feature should work fine but it is experimental. It is not yet clear that it is needed. User feedback is welcome.

This list is only for iterations, access by indexes, and removal by indexes. Accessed lines allow changes but new strings should not contain line separators. Other editor changes during using this list may cause unexpected results and should be avoided.

member.name: P:FarNet.IEditor.SelectedLines
member.summary: Gets the list of selected lines.

remarks.para: WARNING: This feature should work fine but it is experimental. It is not yet clear that it is needed. User feedback is welcome.

This list is only for iterations, access by indexes, and removal by indexes. Accessed lines allow changes but new strings should not contain line separators. Other editor changes during using this list may cause unexpected results and should be avoided.

Recommended ways to change the selected text are: get the selected text by and operate on this string or iterate through selected lines and build a new text, for example using a string builder. Then use if you want new text to be selected after replacement or use + to delete selected and insert new text.

member.name: P:FarNet.IEditor.Strings
member.summary: Gets the string list representation of editor lines.

remarks.para: WARNING: This feature should work fine but it is experimental. It is not yet clear that it is needed. User feedback is welcome.
See MSDN IList(Of T) interface for members, almost all of them are implemented. Not implemented members are: Contains(string), IndexOf(string), and Remove(string).

Note that this string list is almost like any standard list but there are three main differences. 1) Clear() does not removes all lines because one empty line still exists. 2) If the last line is empty then Add() actually inserts before it. 3) If a new string being inserted contains line separators then more than one item is inserted into the list.

member.name: P:FarNet.IEditor.Host
member.summary: Gets or sets a host operating on the editor.
member.remarks:
This property is set by a module in advanced scenarios when an editor is used in a very unusual way. It can be set once, usually by a creator or by a handler on opening. It is not used internally, it is just for avoiding module conflicts.
Example scenario: PowerShellFar may use editors as command consoles. On opening it attaches a host object which is subscribed to the editor events. This approach makes impossible to attach yet another editor host and prevents advanced use of the editor from other modules (if they also follow this technique of attaching a host).

member.name: P:FarNet.ExplorerFilesEventArgs.FilesToStay
member.summary: Gets the list of source files to stay selected and not deleted on move if the job is incomplete.
member.remarks:
If the job is then not processed files should normally stay selected and not deleted on move if the core is told to delete files. Such files have to added to this list.
If the list is empty and the job is incomplete then all input files that still exist in the source stay selected and not deleted.
It is important that the files added to this list must be taken from the input file list.
Choose a proper otherwise source files that should stay may lose selection or even may be deleted because the comparer cannot find them.

member.name: T:FarNet.Explorer
member.summary: Explorer of a virtual file system, file provider and manager, and optionally a panel maker.

remarks.para: Explorers are used for virtual file system navigation and operations on files. They provide files and explorers of other file locations.

Explorers are designed for panels and they normally implement the method. But panels are not required for file operations, explorers can be used for pure file management. Explorers can but do not have to create, configure, and update panels. The core creates default panels for files when needed.

On requests explorers have to create and return new explorers or return nulls. They should never return themselves because the core assumes that each explorer is responsible for its own virtual directory that never change. In other words, once created an explorer should always return the same data, of course, if these data are not changed in the virtual file system.

member.name: M:FarNet.Explorer.#ctor(System.Guid)
member.summary: New explorer with its type ID.

member.name: M:FarNet.Explorer.GetFiles(FarNet.GetFilesEventArgs)
member.summary: Returns the files.

remarks.para: The method should choose the type of the result list carefully. The caller does not make a copy, it users the result as it is. The caller may iterate through the list many times. The caller assumes that the list is never changed. If this is not the case then the method has to return a copy. But it is fine to reuse or update the same list on next calls.
In the "Find" mode the method may be called from a background thread, most of FarNet API is not allowed. In the "Silent" mode any user interactions including error messages are not allowed.

In the "Find" mode the method may be called from a background thread, most of FarNet API is not allowed. In the "Silent" mode any user interactions including error messages are not allowed.

member.name: P:FarNet.Explorer.FileComparer
member.summary: Gets or sets the file comparer.
member.remarks:
Some core procedures have to be able to compare equality of files provided by explorers. This task is difficult: file names are not always unique and same files from different calls are not always represented by same objects. Only file explorers know how to compare their files.
is used by default, i.e. files are compared by names (OrdinalIgnoreCase). is used when an explorer caches its files and always returns the same file objects. is used when an explorer caches its data and always gets the same data attached to files. FileMetaComparer is used in PowerShell scripts. Alternatively, an explorer may implement and use any custom file comparer.
Use case: a panel shows some frequently changed data like current system processes. On update it simply recreates the files and attaches just requested process objects. Thus, the files and data change from call to call and they cannot be used for comparison. If process names are used as file names then names cannot be used for comparison, too, because process names are not unique even within the same call. Solution: a custom comparer that compares process IDs extracted from file data.

member.name: T:FarNet.IFar
member.summary: Main interface which exposes top entries of the FarNet object model.
member.remarks:
The only instance of this class is exposed as the static property of the class . Both names Far and Net are symbolic and make sense only when used together as Far.Net.
The exposed instance provides access to top level Far methods and objects or creates new Far objects like menus, input and message boxes, dialogs, editors, viewers, panels and etc. Further operations are performed on that objects.

Help topic. Use . (Format details: )
It is ignored in GUI and drawn messages.
member.returns: Button index or -1 if canceled, or 0 in the drawn message.

remarks.para: If the option is set then GUI or buttons are not allowed. A message box with no buttons is simply drawn and the execution continues immediately. The caller has to remove the message by redrawing or restoring the screen.
If the option is not set then the message is modal and it shows at least the OK button if there are no buttons provided by the parameters.
In extreme cases when a message contains too many or too long buttons a listbox dialog is used where the listbox items work as buttons.

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.ShowHelp(System.String,System.String,FarNet.HelpOptions)
member.summary: Shows the help topic from a help file.
member.param: Help topic. If this parameter is empty, then the topic "Contents" is used.
Help options describing path and topic.
member.remarks:
This method is used in special cases when is not enough.
The topic parameter describes a help topic and can be in one of the following formats:
"Topic" Reference to a topic in the help file.
":Topic" Reference to a topic from the main Far Manager help file.
"<FullPath\>Topic" Reference to a topic in a help file located in a folder with full or relative path of FullPath. An ending backslash must be added. The reference must not be split on multiple lines. For example, the help file is located in the folder "D:\Far\FarNet\Modules\Foo" and we need the topic "FooInfo" from it: "<D:\Far\FarNet\Modules\Foo\>FooInfo"
"<FullModuleName>Topic" Reference to a topic in a help file located in the same folder as the module with the relative or full path of FullModuleName. The reference must not be split on mutiple lines. For example, we need the help topic "FooInfo" from the help file of the module Foo "D:\Far\FarNet\Modules\Foo\Foo.dll": "<D:\Far\FarNet\Modules\Foo\Foo.dll>FooInfo"

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.ShowHelpTopic(System.String)
member.summary: Shows the help topic from a help file located in the directory of the calling assembly.

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.GetHelpTopic(System.String)
member.summary: Formats the help topic path for HelpTopic properties of various UI classes.
member.returns: Help topic path formatted for the core.
member.remarks:
The help topic path is formatted for a help file located in the directory of the calling assembly. Normally it is a module assembly but it can be any other, e.g. a shared library or a sub-module.
This method is enough for typical use cases and HelpTopic strings are formatted internally. In special cases see for help topic format details.

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.PostStep(System.Action)
member.summary: Posts a handler to be invoked when user code has finished and the core gets control.
member.remarks:
Some core operations are executed only when it gets control, i.e. when user code has finished. Thus, such operations cannot be invoked as a synchronous sequence. This method allows invoke them as an asynchronous sequence.
This mechanism works only when the plugins menu [F11] is available, because it is used internally for stepping. Ensure some FarNet hotkey in the plugins menu. Use [F11] for menu, [F4] to set a hotkey there.
If a step handler starts modal UI without exiting (e.g. dialog) then use if you have another step to be invoked in modal mode (e.g. in a dialog after opening).

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.PostStepAfterKeys(System.String,System.Action)
member.summary: Posts the keys that normally start modal UI and a handler which is invoked in that modal mode.
member.param: Handler to be called in modal mode.

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.PostStepAfterStep(System.Action,System.Action)
member.summary: Invokes a handler that normally starts modal UI and posts another handler which is invoked in that modal mode.
member.param: Handler to be called in modal mode.
member.remarks: Steps in work fine if they do not call something modal, like a dialog, for example. For this special case you should use this method: handler1 normally calls something modal (a dialog) and handler2 is posted to be invoked after that (when a dialog is opened).

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.PostJob(System.Action)
member.summary: Posts a job that will be called by the core when it gets control.
member.remarks:
It is mostly designed for background job calls. Normally other threads are not allowed to call the core. Violation of this rule may lead to crashes and unpredictable results. This methods is thread safe and it allowes to post a delayed job that will be called from the main thread as soon as the core gets control. Thus, this posted job can call the core as usual.
This method should be used very carefully and only when it is really needed.

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.Quit
member.summary: Tells Far to exit if it is possible.
member.remarks: Before sending this request to Far it calls for each module. If all modules return true then Far is called. If there is an editor with not saved changes then Far asks a user how to proceed and, in fact, a user may continue work in Far.

member.name: M:FarNet.IFar.OpenRegistryKey(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Opens the virtual registry key to access the FarNet host data.
member.param: Name or path of the key to open. If it is null or empty then the root key is opened.
Set to true if you need write access to the key.
member.returns: The requested key or null if the key for reading does not exist.
member.remarks:
The returned key has to be disposed after use by Dispose().
For the Far Manager host the root key in the Windows registry is HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Far2 or HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Far2\Users\Xyz if Far is started with the parameter /u Xyz.

member.name: P:FarNet.IFar.CommandLine

If a module is called from the command line (including user menu [F2]) then command line properties and methods may not work correctly. In this case consider to call an operation from the plugins menu [F11].
A module can set the entire command line text if it is called from the command line but not from the user menu.

member.name: T:FarNet.FarFile
member.summary: Abstract panel item representing file, directory, plugin item, or module item.
member.remarks:
Modules may implement derived classes in order to represent their panel items effectively. Alternatively, they may use , already implemented simple property set.
Although this class is abstract all its virtual properties are defined, they get default values and throw NotImplementedException on setting. Thus, derived classes do not have to implement every property, at least has to be defined (in order to be shown in a panel), other properties are implemented only if they are used.

member.name: P:FarNet.Forms.IBaseList.Items
member.summary: List item collection. STOP: see remarks.
member.remarks:
Normally you fill the list with items and set their properties before opening a dialog. After opening this collection is mapped to a control dynamically, i.e. all operations (set, insert, remove and etc.) are displayed immediately. The items themselves are not mapped dynamically, so that if you change an item then you have to reset it explicitly, see the example.
Dynamic mapping is simple, useful and effective when you change (or add, remove) one item at a time (or just a few items). But if you actually recreate all the items then for better performance you have to use before changes and after changes.
member.example:
(PowerShell): how to set an item checked when the dialog is running
# get an item $item = $listbox.Items[3] # change it $item.Checked = $true # set it! $listbox.Items[3] = $item

member.name: M:FarNet.Forms.IDialog.DisableRedraw
member.summary: Disables redrawing of the dialog.
member.remarks:
This method is used to prevent excessive dialog redraws when modifying multiple dialog items.
It increments the internal redraw lock counter. WARNING: you must call (normally when dialog changes are done).

member.name: M:FarNet.Forms.IDialog.EnableRedraw
member.summary: Enables redrawing of the dialog.
member.remarks: It decrements the internal redraw lock counter; when it is equal to 0 the dialog gets drawn. WARNING: it must be called after any call of .

member.name: E:FarNet.Forms.IDialog.Initialized
member.summary: Called when all dialog items are initialized and about to be shown.

member.name: E:FarNet.Forms.IDialog.Closing
member.summary: Called when the dialog is about to be closed (normally a user closes it).
member.remarks:
This event can be used for example for input data validation before the dialog is closed. If event argument is null then the dialog is about to be closed by [Esc] or [F10]; in this case normally you should not stop closing. Otherwise you may check validity of input data. If a user mistake is found you may show a message box (), set focus to the control with a mistake () and finally set event argument to keep the dialog running, so that a user may correct the input or cancel the dialog.
It is not recommended to change control states during this event. Doing so may trigger actions that may be unexpected on closing.

member.name: M:FarNet.IMacro.Remove(FarNet.MacroArea,System.String[])
member.summary: Removes the specified macros or the empty area.
member.remarks: If input names are not provided (null or empty) or there is the only empty name then this method removes the area if it is not used, i.e. contains no macros. Areas with macros cannot be removed.

member.name: M:FarNet.IMacro.Install(FarNet.Macro[])
member.summary: Installs one or more macros in the storage and loads them.
member.remarks:
The method saves current macros, writes data to the storage, and reloads macros.
This operation is not atomic: if there are several macros to install and it fails in the middle then some first macros may be installed and the rest of them are not.
This method fails if macro data are invalid or a macro with the same area and name has be already installed by the same call of this method.

member.name: T:FarNet.IListMenu
member.summary: Menu implemented as a dialog with a list box. It is created by .
member.remarks:
This kind of a menu is more suitable for a list of objects than a set of commands. It provides two kinds of filters: permanent and incremental, both with many options, both can be used together.
Keys:
[CtrlC], [CtrlIns] - copy text of the current item to the clipboard.
[CtrlDown] - this is a default key to open a permanent filter input box.
[Backspace] - remove the last symbol from the incremental filter string (until the initial part is reached, if any).
[ShiftBackspace] - remove the incremental filter string completely, even initial part (rarely needed, but there are some cases).

member.name: T:FarNet.BaseModuleItem
member.summary: Modules implement at least one public not abstract descendant of this class.
member.remarks:
Any FarNet module implements at least one public not abstract descendant of this class.
Normally modules implement one or more actions, descendants of the class. When such a module is just installed or updated FarNet loads it and caches module action attributes. Next time when FarNet starts it does not load the module, it reads the information from the cache. This information is enough to show module menu items, register command prefixes, and etc. The module is actually loaded only when a user invokes one of the actions.
FarNet creates action class instances and calls Invoke() methods every time when a user invokes actions. Thus, only their static data can be shared between calls. These data can be initialized when the Invoke() or the default constructor is called the first time. If these or other data has to be initialized even before actions then the module host should be used.
The module host, descendant of the , can be implemented for advanced scenarios. Unlike module actions the host class instance is created, connected and disconnected once. The moment of creation and call of the method depends on the flag. If it is false (default) then the host is loaded and connected only when one of the module actions is invoked. If it is true (preloaded host) then the module is loaded and the host is connected every time. Preloaded hosts should not be used without good reasons.

member.name: M:FarNet.BaseModuleItem.GetString(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a localized string from .resorces files.
member.returns: Localized string. If a best match is not possible, null is returned.
member.remarks:
It gets a string from .resource files depending on the .
The module has to provide .resources files in its directory:
ModuleBaseName.resources (default, English is recommended)
ModuleBaseName.ru.resources (Russian)
ModuleBaseName.de.resources (German)
...
The file "ModuleBaseName.resources" must exist. It normally contains language independent strings and other strings in a default\fallback language, English more likely. Other files are optional and can be added at any time. Note that they do not have to repeat language independent strings.
See about culture names and MSDN about file based resource management. Use ResGen.exe tool or MSBuild task GenerateResource for binary .resources files generation from trivial .txt\.restext text files or Visual Studio .resx XML files.
If you edit source .resx files in Visual Studio (a very good idea) then ensure they are either excluded from the project or not compiled and embedded into the output assembly.

member.name: T:FarNet.ModuleException
member.summary: Module exception.
member.remarks:
If a module throws exceptions then for better diagnostics it is recommended to use this or derived exceptions in order to be able to distinguish between system, module, and even particular module exceptions.
Best practice: catch an exception, wrap it by a new module exception with better explanation of a problem and throw the new one. Wrapped inner exception is not lost: its message and stack are shown, for example by .

member.summary: Gets or sets the current UI culture.
member.remarks:
Method gets localized strings depending exactly on this property value. This property is set internally to the Far UI culture and normally you do not care of it. But you may want to set it yourself:
To ensure it is the same as the current Far UI culture after its changes.
To use cultures different from the current Far UI culture (for testing or whatever).
To use cultures which are not even known to Far itself (there are no such .lng files).

member.name: T:FarNet.ModuleHostAttribute
member.summary: Module host attribute.

member.name: P:FarNet.ModuleHostAttribute.Load
member.summary: Tells to load and connect the host always. There should be good reasons for 'true'.
member.remarks: If the module host is the only implemented module item then this flag has to be set to true. Otherwise the host has no chances to be used.

member.name: T:FarNet.ModuleHost
member.summary: The module host. At most one public descendant can be implemented by a module.
member.remarks:
In many cases the module actions should be implemented instead of the host (see predefined descendants of ).
If the attribute is true then the host is always loaded. If it is false then the host is loaded only on the first call of any action. A single instance of this class is created for the whole session.
This class provides virtual methods called by the core. Normally the module implements the method. There are a few more optional virtual members that can be implemented when needed.

member.name: M:FarNet.ModuleHost.Connect
member.summary: Override this method to process the module connection.
member.remarks: This method is called once. For standard hosts it is called before creation of the first called module action. For preloadable hosts it is called immediately after loading of the module assembly and registraion of its actions.

member.name: M:FarNet.ModuleHost.Disconnect
member.summary: Override this method to process the module disconnection.
member.remarks:
NOTE: Don't call Far UI, it is not working on exiting. Consider to use GUI message boxes if it is absolutely needed.
The host does not have to unregister dynamically registered actions on disconnection. But added "global" event handlers have to be removed, for example, handlers added to the operator.

member.name: M:FarNet.ModuleHost.Invoking
member.summary: Called before invocation of any module action.
member.remarks:
The module may override this method to perform preparation procedures. Normally this is not needed for a simple module with a single action. It is useful when a complex module provides several actions and wants common steps to be performed by this method.
NOTE: This method is called only for module actions: Invoke() methods and handlers registered by Register*() methods. It is not called on events added by a module to editors, viewers, dialogs or panels.
Example: PowerShellFar starts loading of the PowerShell engine in a background thread on connection. This method waits for the engine loading to complete, if needed. Registered PowerShellFar actions simply assume that the engine is already loaded. But editor event handlers still have to care.

member.name: M:FarNet.ModuleHost.CanExit
member.summary: Can the module exit now?
member.remarks:
This method is normally called internally by the . The module can override this to perform preliminary checks before exit. Note that final exit actions should be performed in .
It is allowed to return false but this option should be used sparingly, there must be really good reasons to disturb normal exiting process. The most important reason is that a user really wants that.
member.returns: True if the module is ready to exit.

member.summary: Tells to ignore the call and allows alternative actions.
member.remarks:
This flag is used when the command is called from a macro.
A handler sets this to true to tell that nothing is done and it makes sense for a caller to perfom an alternative action.
Note: this is not the case when processing has started and failed; the handler should either throw an exception or keep this value as false: fallback actions make no sense, the problems have to be resolved instead.

member.name: T:FarNet.ModuleCommand
member.summary: A command called by its prefix from command lines and macros.
member.remarks:
The method has to be implemented.
Commands are called by their prefixes from command lines: the panel command line and user menu and file association commands. Macros call commands by CallPlugin() (see FarNet Readme.txt).
It is mandatory to use and specify the and the default command prefix .
It is mandatory to set the action ID by System.Runtime.InteropServices.GuidAttribute. The ID has to be generated exactly for this class and it should never change. FarNet uses this ID internally for storing and restoring data. Other modules may use this ID to access and call this action.

member.name: T:FarNet.Panel
member.summary: Module panel. Create it or a derived class instance directly, set properties, add event handlers and open it.

remarks.para: Exposed as and .

Properties of this class are requested by the core quite frequently. For better performance the core caches internal representation of these data. After opening a panel it is recommended to avoid excessive modifications of data.
Some settings often configured before opening: , , , .
After opening changing of panel state properties normally does not cause immediate visual effects. When all changes are done call one of the redraw methods in order to make the changes shown.

Most of UI* methods should not be called directly, they are called by the core on user interaction. Many of them can be overriden in derived classes but this should be done only if explorer methods are not enough.
All Works* members are for internal use only.

member.summary: Navigates to a virtual file system location specified by the explorer and updates the panel.
member.remarks: A new explorer must have the same as the current one.

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.Open
member.summary: Tells to open the panel when the core gets control.
member.remarks:
Normally a panel should be opened when a module is called from panels window (command line, disk menu or plugins menu in panels). If panels window cannot be set current, this method fails.
Other possible reasons of failure: *) another panel has been already posted for opening; *) the module is not called for opening, e.g. it is called to process events.
It is recommended to call this as soon as possible and only then to configure the panel and other data. Technically this method only tries to post the panel for opening and may fail due to the reasons above. Early call and failure avoids jobs for nothing.

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.Open(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calls or depending on the parameter.
member.param: Tells to open the panel as a child of the active module panel, if any.

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.OpenChild(FarNet.Panel)
member.summary: Opens this panel as a child of the parent panel.
member.param: The opend parent panel. Null tells to use the active module panel, if any.
member.remarks: When this panel is opened as a child of the parent panel, the parent is hidden, not closed. When the child closes itself later then the parent is shown again and its state is restored.

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.OpenChildBegin(FarNet.Panel)
member.summary: It is called from before linking the panels together.
member.param: The panel about to be parent.
member.returns: False to cancel opening.
member.remarks:
This method is designed for cases when the child opening depends on the parent. For example the initial current file may depend on the parent current file. When this methods is called the parent is the active panel and its data can be used as usual. The panels are not yet linked together, use the parameter in order to access the parent.
If it returns false or even throws then the parent panel remains opened.

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.SaveState
member.summary: Saves the panel state.
member.remarks: It is called when the panel is about to be offline (pushed or replaced by a child panel). The panel UI state is saved by the core (view and sort modes, etc.). The base method posts the current file to be restored as current. It is important to have the proper .

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.UIClosed
member.summary: Called when the panel has been closed.
member.remarks:
The method releases panel resources. It should not do anything else, the panel has gone.
Overriden methods must call the base. Consider to use try/finally and call the base from finally.
The base method triggers the event and then disposes the .

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.UIClosing(FarNet.PanelEventArgs)
member.summary: Called when the panel is about to be closed.
member.remarks:
There are issues: http://bugs.farmanager.com/view.php?id=602
Far calls this unexpectedly on plugin commands invoked from the command line even if a new panel is not going to be opened and the current one closed. Thus, it can be called more than once.

member.name: M:FarNet.Panel.UIUpdateInfo
member.summary: Called by the core to get the panel info. Use it only when it is absolutely needed.
member.remarks:
Normally you should not use this. It is not recommended for many reasons: *) it is called frequently and can be very expensive; *) it may have problems if panel data are accessed, even for reading.
Consider to update the panel info in other methods. As the last resort use .

member.name: T:FarNet.PanelPlan
member.summary: Panel view plan.
member.remarks:
Normally it is used for . When a panel is opened you can change modes dynamically, but do not forget to reset the list itself, changes in items are not reflected without this.
WARNING: column titles, kinds and custom columns is a sort of low level stuff; if you use this incorrectly the Far may crash.

member.name: M:FarNet.PanelPlan.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new mode as a shallow copy of this.
member.remarks: Use it to create another mode with the same properties and then change a few of them.

member.name: P:FarNet.PanelPlan.Columns
member.summary: Columns info.

remarks.para: All supported kinds: "N", "Z", "O", "S", "DC", "DM", "DA", "C0", "C1", "C2", "C3", "C4", "C5", "C6", "C7", "C8", "C9". Supported Far column kind suffixes may be added to the end, e.g. NR, ST, DCB, and etc., see Far API [Column types].
Default column kind sequence: "N", "Z", "O", "C0", "C1", "C2", "C3", "C4", "C5", "C6", "C7", "C8", "C9". It is exposed as .

Column kind rules:
Specify column kinds only when you really have to do so, especially try to avoid C0..C9, let them to be processed by default.
C0...C9 must be listed incrementally without gaps; but other kinds between them is OK. E.g. C0, C2 is bad; C0, N, C1 is OK.
If a kind is not specified then the next available from the remaining default sequence is taken.
Column kinds should not be specified more than once.

member.name: P:FarNet.PanelPlan.StatusColumns
member.summary: Status columns info.
member.remarks: Use it for status columns in the same way as is used. Column names are ignored.

member.name: P:FarNet.PanelPlan.IsFullScreen
member.summary: Tells to resize panel to fill the entire window (instead of a half).

member.name: P:FarNet.PanelPlan.IsDetailedStatus
member.summary: Tells to display full status info for a file.
member.remarks: Tells to display full status info for a file if Status* are not defined. Otherwise, the status line displays the file name.

member.name: M:FarNet.IUserInterface.RestoreScreen(System.Int32)
member.summary: Restores previously saved by screen area.
member.param: A handle received from SaveScreen. This handle is no longer usable after calling.
member.remarks: For performance sake it redraws only the modified screen area. But if there was screen output produced by an external program, it can't calculate this area correctly. In that case you have to call it with screen = 0 and then with an actual screen handle.

member.name: M:FarNet.IUserInterface.SaveScreen(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves screen area. You always have to call .
member.returns: A handle for restoring the screen.
member.remarks: If right and bottom are equal to -1, they are replaced with screen right and bottom coordinates. So SaveScreen(0,0,-1,-1) will save the entire screen.

member.name: M:FarNet.IUserInterface.SaveUserScreen
member.summary: Copies the current screen contents to the user screen buffer (which is displayed when the panels are switched off).
member.remarks: Normally it is called after and direct console writing. Note: try to avoid these low level operations.

member.name: M:FarNet.IUserInterface.ShowUserScreen
member.summary: Copies the current user screen buffer to console screen (which is displayed when the panels are switched off).
member.remarks: Normally it is called before direct console screen operations and has to be called after. Note: try to avoid these low level operations.

member.name: M:FarNet.IUserInterface.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Writes text on the user screen (under panels).
member.remarks:
This method is called from the panels area in order to simulate classic console output. Calls from other areas are allowed but console output is unexpected and difficult to see.
In PowerShell scripts consider to use the Write-Host cmdlet instead of this method.

member.name: T:FarNet.IRegistryKey
member.summary: Virtual registry key.
member.remarks:
Any opened key has to be disposed by Dispose().
This interface is the simplified version of Microsoft.Win32.RegistryKey. In the Far Manager host it works with the real Windows registry. But modules should not rely on this anyway.

member.name: M:FarNet.IRegistryKey.GetValue(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the value associated with the specified name. If the name is not found, returns the default value that you provide.

member.name: M:FarNet.IRegistryKey.SetValue(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Sets or deletes the specified name\value pair.
member.remarks: Setting the null value deletes the name\value pair.

member.name: M:FarNet.IRegistryKey.GetSubKeyNames
member.summary: Retrieves an array of strings that contains all the subkey names.

member.name: M:FarNet.IRegistryKey.GetValueNames
member.summary: Retrieves an array of strings that contains all the value names associated with this key.

member.name: M:FarNet.IRegistryKey.DeleteSubKey(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes the specified subkey.
member.param: The name of the subkey to delete.
member.remarks: *) The subkey with its own subkeys cannot be deleted. *) It is OK if the specified subkey does not exit.

member.name: P:FarNet.IRegistryKey.Name
member.summary: Retrieves the name of the key.

member.summary: Retrieves the count of subkeys of the current key.

member.summary: Retrieves the count of values in the key.

member.name: T:FarNet.IViewerBase
member.summary: Common viewer events.

member.name: E:FarNet.IViewerBase.Closed
member.summary: Called when the viewer is closed.
member.remarks:
This event is called once for the viewer instance, even if there were several files opened in it, e.g. on [Add], [Subtract] keys the is called every time.
Don't operate on the viewer, it has really gone.

member.name: E:FarNet.IViewerBase.Opened
member.summary: Called when a file is opened in the viewer.
member.remarks: This event can be called more than once for the same viewer instance, e.g. on [Add], [Subtract] keys.

member.summary: Called when the viewer window has got focus.

member.summary: Default action: do not delete a file.

member.summary: The same as plus delete its folder if it is empty. You may set it at any time, i.e. before or after opening.

member.summary: Delete a file if it was not used. The file is used if: *) it was saved; *) there was editor\viewer switching (F6). *) it is opened in another editor or viewer. You should set it before opening.

member.name: F:FarNet.DeleteSource.UnusedFolder
member.summary: The same as plus delete its folder if it is empty. You should set it before opening.
